title: Simple ghat
review_text: Its a simple ghat but wonderful evening can be spent at sunset. the structure of the gate is not that excellent just some pillars. How ever, the ghat of the mighty Ganga river and the sight of new howra bridge from the ghat is awesome. You can have a boat ride in evening enjoy the scenic beauty of the river.

title: Entrance to river walkway.
review_text: The building is nothing special, but it is an entrance point to one of the few access points to the river. There is a lovely walkway that starts here and runs for a couple of kilometres to Eden Gardens bus station. Perfect for an evening/sunset stroll. Along the path you can find boatmen that will take you out on the river for a fee. This walkway is one of the best - if not THE best - things to do in Kolkata.

title: Evening Timepass
review_text: Its a popular location for Kolkata Locals, specially young pairs. You can have the glamorous view of bidyasagar bridge. The place is preferred by young boys n gals for open romance. Not at all recommended to visit with children and elderly people specially in the evening hours.

title: A Well Restored Place, Good place for Fuchka, Pav Bhaji or Boat Ride
review_text:
I am not a great admirer of Mamata Banerjee, the West Bengal CM; but I must admit that Didi's Government has done a great job in restoring this place and given this place a place in the itinerary of City's sightseeing. Kolkata's famous Fuchka, Mumbai's famous Pav Bhaji are being eaten here with equal enthusiasm. A boat ride can be equally enjoyable but the cost was too high at Rs.400 for 30 Minutes. Better to negotiate. 
Passages are well maintained, well lit up. But need good toilet facilities as well.

title: Hangout place of Kolkata
review_text: Princep Ghat is named after the James Princep memorial in that place. Circular Railway connect Princep Ghat with other railway sections of Kolkata. One can reach this place by Bus also. It is a nice place couples as well as for family to hangout.

title: One of those must do Kolkota site.
review_text:
I guess these are are all one of the sites there on every tourist guide book. We went on a weekend and it was really busy. Quite a lot of walking you can do. Gives you a great view of the monumental new howrah bridge. One can opto to take a boat ride from the ghat, watch out for slush on the steps at the ghat.There is also a british monument standing tall before the ghats. In the night when it is lit up, it looks very beautiful. 

It was teething with people from all works of life and you get to feel the energy of Kolkota.

title: Away from the hustle bustle - Your place for peace and beauty
review_text: This is a must visit place if you are in Kolkata. You can stroll at the ghat and then opt for a boat ride - you can enjoy the view of old and new Howrah bridge at both sides with the calmness of water. They take 300/- for half an hour which is expensive but worth it. There are small kiosk for snacks nearby. The river however is very dirty and not maintained. The ghat needs cleaning too.

title: The eye catching vista of the ghat !
review_text: The boat / ferry ride in the river gives you the eye catching view of the famed ghat ( bank ) of this name . As the ferry comes near this ghat you catch the glimpse of the steps and the historic building on the horizon . The famed ghat is a well known landmark of the history . Boat ride is very nominal and frequent . The sheer pleasure of the being near it adds to its glory .

title: huge monument

title: Evening visit to James Prinsep Ghat
review_text: Amazing view of Vivekanand Setu, aka Second Howrah bridge as this bridge too joins the Howrah & Calcutta cities. The panoramic view of a lighted up Vivekanand Setu with boats sailing around is sheer delight to the eyes.

title: A historical place with beautiful view of river and well maintained green areas

review_text: A very quiet place and so close view of Hoghly bridge.Trees are every where and the river.The best time to visit is summer during sunset.

title: Beautiful Ghat of Kolkata along Hoogley river ideal for boating just before Sunset
review_text: Walk along from Babughat along the promenade , approx 1 Km distance, & plan a visit just before Sunset, between 4 to 5 pm. Enjoy a Boat ride, approx Rs 350 for 30 min. Capture the setting Sun with Howrah bridge in backdrop. Feel fresh & rejuvenated. Witness the rituals performed by Hindus along the Ghats. Easily reachable with leisurely walk from Esplanade, along Maidan, Eden Gardens etc.

title: Romance
review_text: This place has its own romance, in holidays this place is crowded like anything due to all the couples coming here to spend some alone time. as it happens the crowd never gives you your alone time. in weekdays or in the mornings this place is silent and very beautiful. people do photoshoots here as well.

title: The Picturesque Ghat of Kolkata
review_text: A stride along the river Ganges and have a pleasant sight of the twilight and the setting sun, the first name that would pop up in a Kolkatan's mind is that of Prinsep Ghat. The destination perfect for the amateur photographers; come evening, late afternoon rather, and the budding shutterbugs flock here to capture the mesmerizing twilight and the sunset. You reach here either from Esplanade, Kolkata or from Howrah. I would suggest a ferry ride from Howrah Ferry ghat to Babughat Kolkata to avoid the bus route in the peak evening hours; this would additionally charge up your mind by the fresh and breezy journey on the lonch

title: Evening walk at River side.
review_text: A place for photography and mostly couples spend some good time here. Its is consider as Gate to Kolkata. You can walk alone and see the view of vidyasagar setu(Bridge) and little ahead the bank of Hoogly river.

title: Check out the elephant!
review_text: This is not a very interesting place to visit, but it has a few interesting floral displays including an elephant. Local people use the site for picnics. For me it was a quick look before catching the commuter train, very quiet on a Sunday, but fun ride as a tourist.

title: Nice place

title: Morning strolling at the Princep ghat
review_text:
In my last visit to kolkata decided to take a stroll at the Princep Ghat. Have not been to this part of the city for more than a decade. Was really surprised to see the transformation of the place and the development of the place. Barring few dirt here and there the place was really serene and beautiful with a kolkata charm in it. Went back to my childhood days when our parents used to bring us here for a outing in the evening. 
Ended the walk with a steaming tea from earthen pot and some light snacks. really an wonderful experience.

title: A pictured treat to the History.
review_text:

title: Nice View but lacks maintenance - Skip Boat ride
review_text:
I visited Prinsep Gaht hoping to spend a nice evening. We went for the boat ride where the person at the helm just wanted to stop at a place in the river rather than row it . We paid for a one hour ride but could hardly spend 15 mins because he was rowing the boat at such a slow speed that there was no wind. When asked to go back he suddenly got all the energy to drive it faster. 
The place has good view of the river and the lighted Hooghly bridge but it lacks basic maintenance. There was no clean place to sit over there.

title: Colonial era structure
review_text: Prinsep Ghat is a Kolkata destination for tourists to click photos under the colonnades of this British era structure. A two-minute walk away from this structure, across the train level crossing, is the promenade by the Hooghly River. You can hire a rowboat for 30 minutes and be rowed under the long, new Howrah suspension bridge...

title: Park

title: For an evening by the Hooghly
review_text: When in Kolkata, with nothing much to do in the evening, decide to spend your time here, under the Vidyasagar Setu. With the view of the river, lights from above the bridge glistening in the waters, ferries waving across, a pair of railway tracks and that picturesque archway - photographers even choose to do pre-wed shoots here. The cool breeze of the river is sure to take away all the bustles the city offers continuously!

title: Visit in Evening
review_text: Nice place to sit in the evenings and see the ferries go along. There is a local train station just behind the ghat which you need to cross to reach here. New bridge runs just above your head and gives a good feel of city when the lights are turned on.

The second bridge looks splendid in the evening, when its all lit up.This place is an ideal visit for your gang of friends as well.

title: Iconic Calcutta

title: Perfect spot for a quiet evening

It felt so serene -- the view of the water stretching far and wide, no tourists in the background, just us quietly cherishing our moments of togetherness. Friends who have been there at other times say that the boat ride can be a beautiful experience. I would like to check that out sometime. More

title: Historical Place
review_text:
Named after James Princep in the year 1893 when British ruled in India. It is next to the 2nd Hooghly Bridge beside the River Hoogly. 
You will really like the ambiance of this place especially in the evening and early morning. The Sunset and Sunrise are beautiful here. So is the lighting and reflection of 2nd Hoogly Bridge on the river. If you want, you can also rent a ferry boat for a ride across the Hooghly river. 
This place has been recently famous among the photographers, especially for a pre-wedding photoshoot.

title: Good place for good pictures

title: Not to be missed
review_text: This is why people go to Kolkata. The river is its lifeline and its main attraction. And if you haven't been to Prinsep Ghat, close to where you now have the Millennial Park, then you really haven't seen the heart of Kolkata. Best time to visit: late summer evening or better still, July or august evening, when the river has all of that gorgeous muddy monsoon water. Go around 4.30-5, wait til the dusk falls, and the lights come on. Its dreamy and magical and wistful! Your heart is full. Millennial Park stretches almost till the Howrah bridge, but you get an awesome view of both the old bridge and the new, the 2nd Hooghly bridge. and the boats floating by or docked. It is what indelible memories are made of More

title: One of the best spots in the city for a stroll

One can sit down on a bench and talk to friends and family members while sipping tea from clay pots and enjoying 'jhalmuri', Kolkata's favorite snack. The breeze coming from the river is always refreshing. In summer, go there in the evening to cool down.

title: Nice Place with Historical background of Kolkata
review_text: The memorial of James Prinsep, the founder of Asiatic Society in Kolkata during British Raj, is renovated and maintained nicely. A small park around the memorial is a nice place to spend some leisurely time in morning and evening. In the evening the memorial being lit up with Lights. In the background the Vivekananda setu makes the overall place graceful. Just a walk for few meters, one can cross the railway station of Prinsep Ghat, find the beautifully maintained Ghats along the Hooghly river. One can take boat ride down the memory lane. Walk through the greenery and an Walk a way till Babughat. Lot of street foods available. Nice view of the Hooghly river with two iconic bridges (Vivekananda Setu and Howrah Bridge) on both the side. Lot of young couples spend their romantic time all around the park. More

review_text:
Just beside the second Hooghly bridge (Vidyasagar Setu), Princep Ghat has a British-built monument dedicated to the eminent Anglo-Indian scholar, James Princep. 
Further on, there is a quaint railway platform that is serviced by EMU trains under the Calcutta Circular Railway management. And beyond the railway tracks is the 'ghat', from where the local boatmen take people for short boat-rides on the river.

title: Leisure time
review_text: The monument in memory of James Princep, has been around for more than a century. But the area has been beautified and face-lifted in recent times, to make it more tourist friendly. The monument itself is heritage to Kolkata, somewhat well maintained. I say somewhat as though the structure is painted and maintained and well lit to make it attractive from a distance, you will find it to be dirty from close quarters. Like many other monuments in Kolkata, this place also needs a lot of daily-maintenance. The adjacent area has a lot of greenery and maintained pretty well (the Princep Ghat circular rail station is also pretty picturesque). The walkway and benches all along the river side are well though out and a good place for a walk or just to spend some time and enjoy the nature. The 'ghat' itself is cleaner than the others (as bathing and idol immersion are prohibited here) and a good place to sit for sometime and enjoy the beauty of the river Hoogly. More

title: Nice views, nice location, full of couples
review_text:
We took a path to this place that went through a local train station (with a local train waiting there) and we had to cross the platform and train tracks to reach here. By mistake, but nice. 

On one side of the train tracks is the ghat itself and the river - a tree-covered and picnicky place - where you can see the ships and boats in the Hoogly river and also the Vidyasagar Setu (bridge). This was a peaceful area but it apparently gets crowded in the evenings with families. 

Prinsep Ghat itself, a victorian era building, is also decent and the view of the building just below the bridge is very nice. But the whole place is busy with college/school couples doing what they do and dudes trying to "sneak a peek". Decent for a quick visit. More

title: People had contributed money for building this Memorial to Indologist Prinsep way back in 1841.
review_text:
Life story of James Prinsep is amazing. He barely lived 40 years, 20 of which he spent in India and in these small years he achieved so much. He is credited to decipher Brahmi script which we are so proud today, apart from Kharoshti, he did improvements in weights and measures, coinage and even help building a canal. 
No wonder when he died at a young age people contributed money to make a memorial for him next to Fort William. Today Prinsep Ghat has a memorial to him, a Railway Station and a Ghat which gives fabulous view of River Ganga or Hooghly. 
Really loved going around and absorbing the atmosphere and taking photographs of the vicinity. More

There is a circular railway which has a stop at Prinsep Ghat. But hawkers were busy around the tracks, clamouring for people to purchase their stuff.

review_text:
We snapped a few shots of the Prinsep Ghat, but continued on to the riverside walk. Highly recommend as a nice slice of Kolkata life. Trees shade most of the promenade with great views of the bridge and passing boats as well as the occasional train rumbling down the tracks. Benches are many but are hard to come by as they are always (at least at dusk on the weekends) occupied by young lovebirds. People watching is fantastic and photo opportunities are varied and many. 

Do walk north toward the Howrah Bridge. You can sample delicious and cheap Kolkata street food such as phuchkas, paw bhaji, papri chat, jal muri and more! Then you can go into Scoop for ice cream and great views from the first floor. 

Best time to go is just before dusk. Wear comfortable walking shoes and bring an umbrella in case of passing showers. You can also take one of the many boats up and down the river (prices seem to be INR300 for 30 mins) for nice sunset views if you can't score a bench. 

Taxis easy to get once you've had your fill and want to head out. Very relaxing and chilled out way to pass a couple of hours in Kolkata. Great change of pace after frenetic College Street and heaving New Market experiences! More

title: Best public place to enjoy the river
review_text:
Finally, Kolkata has a riverside public promenade which is great. 

The very first view of the astounding monument of Prinsep ghat will keep you engrossed for quite some time before you can even think of walking away to the riverside. The monument is used in almost all movies that are shot in Kolkata. This part has a great green lawn where you can plan a picnic or you may also decide to sit in one of those chairs around the place. 

Take a short walk & you reach the circular railway station level crossing. Cross the tracks and you have the majestic view of the river Ganges. You see the great hoogly bridge from right below it. Beautiful boats, colored in Blue & White, will take tourists for a private ride at a reasonable rate. It's a must on a nice day. 

The promenade along the river is nicely paved with sitting arrangements. Take a walk all the way north toward the outram ghat and beyond. There's an eatery called 'scoop' which serves snacks and great ice creams. The view from it's first floor sitting area is awesome. More

title: Beautiful place with a touch of history
review_text: Built in the 1840s this remains one of Kolkata's oldest recreational spots where people flock in the evening and dawn. It is a rather romantic spot for a leisurely stroll along the river, go boating or just sit on the benches admiring the gorgeous river views. It has a gorgeous monument dedicated to James Prinsep in Gothic Greek architectural style which has been well restored by the state department. It is beautifully lit in the evenings. It also has a small railway station and a jetty that was once used by all British Royals for embarkation and disembarkation. This is one of the ghats with a lot of history and beauty. title: The most peaceful, green and serene place in Kolkata
review_text:
Prinsep Ghat is one of the oldest recreational spots of Kolkata. The Ghat was named after James Prinsep. Located along the banks of the beautiful Hooghly River (River Ganges), the Ghat is surrounded by greenery and overlooked by the Vidyasagar Setu. Around evening, people flock the place and enjoy long strolls along the bank. There are many food-stalls nearby that sell a variety of street delicacies. There is also 50 year old ice-cream cum fast-food joint near the Ghat, which is popular among the crowds, especially the youngsters. People can conduct rituals and take a bath or go for boat rides. The short river cruises on the traditional wooden boats and speedboats are available nearby. 
After the recent beautification of the Prinsep Ghat premises with gardens, lawns, park benches and shady trees, the Ghat has become a very peaceful retreat for nature lovers. You can take a nice long walk along the riverside through the gardens and trees. More

review_text:
This is a small park with a structure built in the British era,in memory of James Prinsep. 
This is located just below the massive Second Hooghly bridge,on Kolkata side 

Went there day before yesterday late afternoon to play with my kids and felt that this place should have been better maintained. Lot of families were enjoying,but surely looked as if the place is a lover's den,with couples below every tree and on every chair. 

The structure in the middle has terrific lighting,and when the lights are lit in the early evening,it looks fabulous. The ground is almost devoid of green grass,and should have been better maintained. The litter boxes are full of spit-marks and looks downright dirty. 
There is a family of elephants (made by moss over some permanent structure) which attracts both children and 'selfie' takers ! 
Overall a very good place to spend sometime with your kids 

Toilets are located at the back and only street food are available near the Prinsep Ghat Railway station,a stone's throw away from this attraction More

You can sit around the river bank and just hear the water and see the two howrah bridges.. Or you can pay 300 bucks and take a 30 minute boat ride. 

I opted for the latter and I am happy I did... Its awesomely fabulously amazing.. Peace, hearing the sound of oars against the water and just gazing at the sky has its own charm. Please do it.

title: A lovely and romantic setting
review_text:
Prinsep Ghat is lovely place for the whole family. One can go there any point in time of the day or evening. The promenade there is great for jogging or just a stroll across the Hooghly River with traditional boats always patiently waiting to take you on a Hooghly river cruise. They charge a standard rate of 300Rs. and It's worth it. If you have 30 minutes to spare; it's a refreshing boat ride especially during winters. The boat takes you to the center of the river, under the bridge and back. After that have some 'adraki cha" (ginger tea) and if you like, walk a little more from one end to another, indulge in some street food right on the promenade and then head back. You might also like to take your camera along to capture some beautiful shots of the new bridge that connects the two land masses. 

The 'ghat' was built in 1841 during the British Raj, along the Kolkata bank of the Hooghly River in India. The Palladian porch in the memory of the eminent Anglo-Indian scholar and antiquary James Prinsep was designed by W. Fitzgerald and constructed in 1843 More

James Princep for all his enthusiasm in research and analysis, died a premature death at the young age of forty one. The Ghat was opened to public in the year 1843. In its initial years, all the royal British entourages used the Princep Ghat jetty for embarkation/disembarkation. review_text:

You can't afford to miss the Hooghly river view and Vidyasagar Setu in the background from Princep Ghat.

title: Place for an evening walk in Kolkata
review_text:

Parking is free. You can park your car and sit inside and chat with your friends, otherwise you can enter the Princep Ghat. As soon as you enter, you need to cross the railway lines, and then there are benches to sit and cemented ghat-side (river bank) to walk around. Plenty of small eateries as well as a few reputed ones. 

Place is nice for a walk, parking is usually available and free. No hassles. No entry fee. You can click a few selfies. Overall those looking to take their mates out for a walk, can go to Princep Ghat. 

Just one negative, few may find this place a little stinky in some areas. More

review_text: Named after versatile Anglo-Indian, orientalist, James Princep in the year 1841 at a cost of Rs 12000 on the eastern banks of river Hoogly. Built in Greek and Gothic style a Palladian porch. It’s a white beautiful heritage monument with well maintained big lawn. Unlike the crowd of Kolkata, it appears that not too many visitors come here. A good place to relax and if you want to go for a walk a nice park is adjacent to it which runs along the river Hoogly.

title: A place to relax
review_text: Come in the eveving with your friend or family...enjoy the boat ride on the ganges... watch the sunset and a dollop of ice cream at the scoop or the Fuchka ... brings the term to its real meaning... City of Joy

title: A favourite 'Ghat' of Kolkata
review_text: This place use to be a deserted and un-inhibited once , but now due to the beautification and maintenance this place surely deserves recommendation. A huge pillar structure dedicated to Sir James Princep after whom the place has been named. The river quietly flows beside the jetties and the railway station along with the greenery and the avenue makes this place a heaven for the young love birds of Kolkata. Visitors to the city must visit the place for the unique composition created by the 'Vidyasagar Setu ' (2nd Hoogly Bridge) and the deserted jetties on the other side of the bank during sunsets. This place is also a must go for the photographers trying some nice landscapes by the city. More

title: Religious place-takes you back in time
review_text: Nice place to rever your ancestors, overlooking the river, chant mantras, offer puja. Though you need to be careful of the monkeys around-they can snatch anything you have on hand,Administration should also spend some time in cleaning the ghat of garbage etc

title: One time visit !
review_text: It was visit with friends, but not suitable for young children. We took the boat and it was definitely a pleasant experience. The surroundings were a bit creepy and will probably not visit again.

title: Good place to take a stroll in the evening
review_text:
Went there on an evening with the kids. They loved running around the open spaces, sitting on the grass covered elephants and unleashing their energy in running around the various pillars of the Princep Memorial. 

Was good to know about James Princep and his contributions to India and how people liked him so much that they constructed the memorial using their own funds. 

We took a walk along the ghats, there were a lot of people who swarm the ghat in the evening to see a glimpse of the Hooghly river during sunset. The place is crowded but you can walk at your own pace and explore the greenery, you can sit on one of the numerous benches too if you are lucky. 

We took a boat ride in the evening, I wish the queue system there was better managed. It is good to see the New Howrah Bridge well lit up from the ghat. You can also see the Old Howrah Bridge from there. 

Overall, a good place to take a stroll in during evening hours. More

title: EPITOME OF ROMANCE
review_text: It is to me the Gateway of EASTERN INDIA.In evening the wind and the river is best place to fight against the humid of the city.

title: Historical Ghat with a decent view
review_text: Liked that there was sufficient information about the monument and the ghat. The place can be maintained better, in terms of cleanliness.

review_text: Princep ghaat is a place to spend quite and relaxed evening .Ghaat and adjoining is beautifully illuminated at night.There is also a local train station as well near ghaat.During evenings you can see small dongi with lanterns floating in the river

title: Prinseps Ghat is marvelous.
review_text:
This ghat in the name of a great town planner Prinseps is on the western bank of Hooghly river. It is beautiful site in the evening & night as it is well lit. One can see Vivekanand setu (new bridge) & its reflection in the river from here. It is also lover's paradise. 
From here onwards one can stroll along the western bank of Hooghly river along Strand road for 3-4 km with well lit pathway & some eateries along the foot path. Benches at short distances are mos sought after place after a walk.

title: Riverside charm
review_text: Princep Ghat is one of the most charming spots in Kolkata, if one overlooks the litter. Now there is a long paved pathway running along the river, where one can relax on a stone bench and take pictures of the boats sailing on the river.

title: Remebrance of ancient Calcutta
review_text: It is on the bank of river Hooghly ( popularly known as 'Ganga' ). The serene beauty with the long "Vidyasagar Setu" ( 2nd. Hooghly bridge ) along side will mesmerize you. During the immersion ceremony of goddess 'Durga' after 4 days of worship, this place attracts a mammoth gathering till late night. The romantic traveller may hire a country boat at a very nominal cost per hour to have a trip on the river for an hour or so. It will surely freshen up your mind. As the place is well connected by road and Circular rail, it is easily accessible from any part of Kolkata. After evening the place becomes some what lonely. More

title: Me time & we time
review_text: This is a place by the Ganges, where the architecture, concept always enthralls me. If you just want to have a me time, visit the place be there with your favorite book/camera/drawing copy/book..feel the breeze of Ganges and immerse in yourself. If you wish to just sit with your beloved holding hands and be quite this is the place. Only request is please don't create a mess there throwing tit bits there and dont shout and scream with a huge gang. please be soft and enjoy the sunset which we can hardly view properly from our balcony.

title: Great place to spend one calm evening
review_text: The location is awesome, just beside the Ganges, calm and no crowd! Yes, many have not explored Princep Ghat and are unaware of this place. If you want to change your taste, release the tension of the hectic Kolkata life, just drop to Princep ghat in one evening, specially Sunday. The KMC also beautified the place and there are ample place to sit. But one will love the ghat actually.

title: Stunning setting
review_text:
Kolkata in all its glory and power came alive at the Princep Ghat. At least for me. 

It was a rainy day and the sky was overcast. I walked along the train tracks next to the river. And finally at the Ghat, came the sight of the river in its full glory with the two iconic bridges on either side of it 

Took a boat ride (cost about 300 bucks) to do a half an hour jaunt. The best 300 rupees I've ever spent. The initial lull and ebb in the river, and the gentle sway of the boat with an overcast sky. Then 10 minutes into the ride, a lightning striking at the distance and the boatman riding a bit more sppedily to the shore. And the rain hitting us while still being mid-river. Such a divine experience to be drenched under that overcast sky. Such a super memorable visit More

title: The James Princep Ghat
review_text: Princep Ghat used to be a jetty where large boats could anchor during the early 20 the Century. Now, with the river silting, you have only country boats coming in. The area has been developed recently by the Government with lovely promenades, glistening statues and an amphitheatre which hosts cultural programmes through the winter. The Ganges flows next door, making the walk a pleasant one. You could park your car and stroll from Princep Ghat right upto Babu Ghat (about 2 kms) on the lovely riverfront "Strand" as we call it in Kolkata. Eateries available, with SCOOP being the star attraction for the youngsters; you could see the lovely Second Hooghly Bridge illuminated right above you More

title: NADIA KI PAAR
review_text: Situated in the western part of Kolkata along the banks of river Ganga.Good place to see the river and to time out for lots of indian snacks and ice-cream. Cruise to river. Lover's paradise.

title: A Piece of History on the bank of the Ganges
review_text: The Prinsep Ghat is a piece of history on the bank of the Ganges - Hooghly river. It is named in memory of eminent orientalist James Prinsep. The majestic gate-like structure leads to a jetty over the adjoining river-front. It is a nice place for a stroll and for viewing the nearby bridge and historic Fort William..

title: What a View!
review_text:
The river flows and has done so since the beginning of time it seems. Here the past meets the present and creates a symphony that heals the soul. From this ghat both the bridges over Hooghly (or Ganga, as the locals call it) are visible. The monument dedicated to James Princep is beautiful and makes for an amazing view against the Vidyasagar setu. 

Evening sets in and the whole area lights up like a fairyland. The crimson sun sinks below the horizon leaving behind the beautiful streaks of ochre, purple and indigo... it was an amazing evening. The street stalls come alive with all sorts of yummy fare! I gorged on them! Nevertheless, I returned with great memories! More

title: Never visit during public holidays
review_text: I went to Princep Ghat on the 1st of January, 2015. It was a VERY wrong day to go there. It is usually a pretty quite place with less crowd but on 1st Jan, the place was crowded, there was a fair which added to the noise and ofcourse the garbage strewn everywhere. What saddens me is that Kolkata does have some amazing places but thanks to some of the people and their vandalism that such places get destroyed. The James Princep Memorial with the Vidyasagar Setu in it's backdrop is every budding photographer's delight .............yet, some vandals have managed to destroy it by spray painting filth on one part of the structure. I need to go back on a weekday and in the early hours to be able to appreciate the place more. My three star rating is due to the filth, the crowd and the loud noise along with the spray painted rubbish on one f the walls. I hope I can give it a higher rating , soon. More

review_text: The best time to visit is an early winter morning or even during monsoon if the rains don't bother you. title: A Nice Place to Spend an Evening
review_text:
A monument was built by the Britishers to honour the memory of James Prinsep, an orientalist in the 19th. century on the eastern bank of the Hooghly river opposite the Fort William. It was lying in a dilapidated condition till about the beginning of the 21st. century. The West Bengal government restored and beautified the monument and it stands gorgeously today with night illumination and a beautiful lawn on its eastern side. The city's circular railway has its terminus station here. The majestic Vidyasagar Setu , a bridge across the Hooghly river adds to the eye candy of the entire surrounding. The riverside also has been beautified with a beautiful walkway starting from here and up to about two miles to the north upto Babughat. The walkway has fountains and plenty of neatly attired street food vendors sell the most lip smacking delicacies tha Kolkata street food can offer. The old man of war jetty is an added attraction as is the restaurant or rather ice cream parlour which has been there since my childhood days, 
The monument as such is a huge covered porch painted in gleaming white and a nice cover for people who would not like to sit on the lawn outside. The walk by the river with the circular railway track on one side and the occasional train trudging along is a treat indeed. More

title: Lover's Paradise
review_text: A memorial for James Prinsep, the eminent orientalist who have deciphered Kharoshthi and Brahmi scripts of ancient India, this place is built on the backdrop the 2nd Hooghly Bridge (Vidysagar Setu) and near to the gate of Fort William. This place is also accessible via Prinsep Ghat station on the Circular railway. The best time to visit this place is in the evening. This memorial is nice photo stop with the backdrop of 2nd Hooghly Bridge. Boating rides on the Ganges is also available in the nearby ghat, which is very popular among couples.

title: Makeover magic

title: Balm for the tired soul !
review_text:
Princep Ghat is one of the most serene places in Kolkata. The place has been given a grand makeover by the Chief Minister and this has benefitted the public to a great extent. The entire promenade has been beautified with green walking paths , right up to Outram Ghat . There are do many benches all along the river side that it's a great to the eyes to sit there and enjoy the views of the river flowing past. One can walk into the more crowded areas which have street food stalls , fresh and tasty to more secluded places to sit and listen to music on your I pod , whist watching the sunset ..... If one wishes , you could also take a leisurely boat ride along th driver in those quaint barges with covered hoods .It is a favourite hangout for couples but that dies not mean families are not comfortable there ... 
If time would permit , I would love to visit the place every morning for a wonderful beginning to the day.......away from the hustle and bustle of the city ! 
Do have the small cups of black , lemon tea,,,, refreshing ! More

title: A place to soothe yourself near the river !!
review_text: Built in 1841 and named after orientalist James Prinsep in the British rule this ghat is a tourist cum lovers spot now. title: A Beautiful River Walk
review_text: Come to Princep ghat in the evening and enjoy the sunset on the River Hoogly. The Princep monument is all lit up in the evenings and it is a beautiful view under the Vidyasagar Setu that looms large over it. It is a good place for photo shoot with the monument and the bridge at the background. Take a country boat ride under the bridge (charge around Rs300) and hum a rabindrasangeet or any song and enjoy the cool breeze over the River Hoogly. The well kept walk under the shade of the big trees and small garden is a perfect place to have a leisurely stroll while enjoying the views of the river. One can walk the whole length from Babu Ghat to Princep Ghat. Have a Jhal Muri or Pav Bhajji to end the perfect evening with your partner, friend or family. More

title: Definite visit
review_text:
You should have to visit this place in the evening. You will be enthralled by the 2 hoogly river bridges (Rabindr sethu and Vidyasagar Sethu). a must do is to take a boat ride (the old hand row boats) on the ganges in the evening. It provides a cool respite from the otherwise humid Kolkata weather. Once you re done with the boat ride have the pav bhaji from any of the vendors vying to get your attention. Then cool yourself further with an ice cream soda from Scoops. dont miss this thing as you dont get this anywhere else in Kolkata. Once you r done you can end your evening with a nice stroll on the banks of the rivr which the KMC have maintained quite well. 
PS:You can visit this place to see the immersion of goddess durga during sept-oct or saraswati puja during jan-feb. One piece of advice...its gonna be overcrowded, but the immersion of durga into the ganges is a site to see. You should go there on during the day on the last day of the uja. You will be able to see the trditional bengali families coming together to immerse their favorite goddess. 

Its a sight to behold. More

title: One spot glimpse of Kolkata
review_text:
If anyone wants to get a summarized view of the city of Kolkata, this is the place to be and enjoy the majestic view of the city along the river banks. Right next to the Vidyasagar Setu, along the banks of the hooghly river, one gets a enchanting breeze of the river along with the lush green surroundings acting as a picture perfect backdrop for the city of Joy. The location is a legacy of the city of Kolkata. 

The location is easily accessible and well connected from Esplanade and Babughat. The nearest ferry head/ghat is Babughat and one can also get to this location via suburban trains from Dum Dum / Majerhat by getting down at the Princep ghat Circular Railway station. The ideal time to visit this place is during the high tides of river Hooghly and the evening hours of dusk. More

title: Stately Grace
review_text:
Princep Ghat is just opposite the St George's Gate of Fort William, both harking back to a slower statelier and more graceful era circa 19th century. Princep Ghat, a legacy not a relic of the colonial past, is a big colonnaged hall open all round with a matching slanting roof bang on the Hoogly river( a disty of the Ganges, 
It has been restored and is well maintained and the very popular venue of a classical music fest every winter. 
I am fortunate that I cross it every time I go for golf to the Fort William Course. The grounds are a favourite location for morning walkers doing their calisthenics.

title: Good for photography
review_text: Princep Ghat with the iconic second Hooghly Bridge or Vidyasagar Setu in the background is famous among photographers. The place enthralls you with its beauty. Come here for photos, or sit by the river, or catch up with friends at the park, you'll love it to the core.

title: Beautiful Structure
review_text:
One of the few places in India which can boast of a riverfront promenade - a walk from Babughat to the Prinsep ghat on an winter evening along the river Hoogly in Kolkata is sure to remain etched in your minds. The promenade is lined with walkaways and gardens and the Vidyasagar Setu alias 2nd Hoogly bridge looms large in the background. The walk will culminate at a place where one finds a pavilion in the Greek architectural style. It back from the Raj era when it used to be a favourite haunt of the Europeans of Kolkata for taking in the cool evening air. It has since been restored and is beautifully illuminated at night. The pavilion was built in 1841 in memory of James Prinsep - a prominent East India Company employee and an indologist. after his death the prominent citizens of Kolkata raised a subscription to build the monument which became a landing place for the visiting Europeans. 
It is also possible to enjoy a country boat ride on the Hoogly from here. However, it is advisable not to venture out alone in this area too late into the night or early mornings as the surrounding areas are not well developed. 
You can reach Prinsep Ghat from Sealdah station via the Chakra Rail - one of the earliest railway systems within the city. More

title: Princep Ghat
review_text:
If you are a traveler and interested in the history of Kolkata, this is a place you must visit. The curious monument bearing the name of Mr Princep, an accountant with the erstwhile East India Company stands in the bank of the Ganges, now brightly lit and maintained properly, courtesy the new government. You walk in past the monument on your left and have to cross a railway tract passing through the walkway guarded by boom barriers which always remain closed. The Princep Ghat station is just stone throw away. As you walk along the paved pathway on the bank of river Hooghly (The Ganges to the outsiders), you seem to be transported to few hundred years back. You would be thrilled to know that British came in to India through this waterway,and had built a fort on the bank of Hooghly called Fort William. title: Ideal place to spend a lazy evening
review_text:
We visited Princep ghat at sunset on 31st Dec. Not sure if the colorful lights were due to the New Year eve programme taking place there, but it was beautiful and clean. Nice place to spend a quiet evening soaking in views of the Hoogly river and the towering 2nd Hoogly bridge (Vidyasagar setu), enjoying a nice stroll with pleasant cool breeze and a fistful of warm ghoti garam. If I were living in Kolkata, I'd probably visit this place often. 

This place doesn't have stairs but one has to cross rail tracks so I wouldn't suggest visiting if you are using a wheelchair. 

PS- The washrooms were in pathetic condition so it would be better not to use them. More

title: Experience Sunrise & Sunset from here!
review_text:
The place was very very dirty previously..now it's cleaned up..but personally I think being one of the oldest spot of Kolkata, this place needs more attention.. 
Located on Strand road, Princep Ghat is one of the oldest and most beautiful Monuments in the city of Kolkata. It was built in 1841 as a memorial to James Princep, a brilliant scholar who was the secretary of “The Asiatic Society” from 1832-1838,and is best remembered for deciphering the Kharosthi and Brahmi scripts of ancient India.The Ghat was opened to public in the year 1843.The old Monument was restored by West Bengal Govt. in 2001.The Monument is a unique one..built in Greek and Gothic style. 
Famous song 'Piyu Bole" of Parineeta movie have been shooted here.. 
Experience Sunrise and Sunset from this Ghat..take a Nouka Ride from this Ghat during Sunset..2nd Hooghly Bridge with the backdrop of Sunset will be awesome!Photographers would like to capture the seen...surely! 
Enjoy Chakra Rail ride also :D More

title: An evening by the River Hooghly
review_text: This memorial structure on the banks of the Hooghly River is dedicated to James Princep (scholar and antiquary). It provides an excellent backdrop to the second Hooghly Bridge (Vidyasagar Setu) and portrays Greek and Gothic architecture providing some good photo opportunities. Nice place to spend an evening; enjoy the breeze, take a sit by the river side or take a leisurely walk with the sun setting-in in the backdrop of the river. There are some local boats (very basic) which offer a ride on the river for a small fee; also you can find some road side eateries around.
